turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Exemplary Women of Antiquity.
turn.1: What can you tell me about the Women of Antiquity?
turn.2: Exemplary Women of Antiquity Exemplary Women of Antiquity is a set of paintings produced between 1495 and 1500 by Andrea Mantegna.
turn.3: What are some of the paintings?
turn.4: They show the Carthaginian noblewoman Sophonisba poisoning herself to avoid being paraded in a Roman triumph, the Roman Vestal Virgin Tuccia proving her chastity by carrying water in a sieve, Judith with the head of Holofernes and Dido holding Sychaeus's funeral urn.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: Infrared reflectography has uncovered a signature on the back of "Judith" reading "And.a Mantegnia. ." (Andrea Mantegna painted [it]). " Sophonisba" and "Tuccia" are egg-tempera on poplar panel, whilst "Judith" and "Holofernes" are glue-tempera on linen canvas.
turn.8: All four works are in monochrome or grisaille and imitate relief sculpture, a style very popular in the Mantuan court at the time thanks to the expense of importing marble from neighbouring Italian states and the lack of sculptors at court.
turn.10: Another example was the same artist's "The Introduction of the Cult of Cybele at Rome" from around the same times.
turn.11: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.12: "Tuccia" and "Sophonisba" originally had the same dimensions.
